Mar 27

Let’s Stop Making Parenthood a Career Penalty

It’s always exciting when a coworker brings her new baby into the office for the first time. You bend down to the stroller, take a peek behind the blanket covering the tiny infant’s face, and exclaim, “Aww! What a beautiful little career killer you’ve got there!”

Okay, you’ve probably never actually said this. But have you thought it? If so, I wouldn’t judge you.

It’s the sad truth that the higher up you look in most organizations, the less women you see — less than 5% of the S&P 500 CEOs are female.

Why is this? You might think that women choose to give up their careers after bringing a child into the world, but to Anna Auerbach, co-CEO and co-founder of Werk, this is wrong. In Auerbach’s view, “ambitious women who happen to have families” are often forced to give up their jobs due to lack of flexibility.

“Women are driven by more than title and pay — they’re driven by balance,” Auerbach said at a recent HubSpot event. “We don’t want parenthood to become a penalty.”

As Auerbach aptly pointed out, women (and men too for that matter) don’t magically lose their ambition once they become parents; or caretakers of ill, disabled, or special needs family members; or any other circumstance that comes with life. They’re still the same ambitious people they always were, but because they can no longer operate within a strict nine-to-five, they tend not to reach for that promotion, or quit the demanding job in favor of something a little less taxing.

And isn’t that a pity? Just think of all the brilliant people not working to their full potential (or desire!) right now simply because they’re jostling a baby on their hip, and need to schedule their meetings around nap time.

It was with this in mind that Auerbach founded her company Werk, a marketplace for flexible jobs. It’s here that women and men of all life circumstances can find what she terms “compatibility” — making work, well, work around whatever it is that’s most important to an individual.

By surfacing challenging flexible jobs to high-quality candidates, Auerbach hopes to see greater diversity in leadership in coming years. “We’re [offering] flexibility as a leadership advancement solution,” she said. “Our hope is to become the LinkedIn of flexible jobs.”

How to Build a More Flexible Workplace, From Wherever You Sit

But surfacing flexible jobs to qualified candidates is only one part of the solution. Because the problem of overly rigid work environments is systemic, Auerbach urged workers at all levels to take action in support of flexibility.

Here are a few of her recommendations:

  • For the c-suite: care about this issue. “The most senior leaders need to bless this as something that’s really important,” Auerbach said. Unless people see the CEO walking the walk in addition to talking to talk, they’ll worry that truly flexible work isn’t sanctioned.
  • For managers: lead by example. Need to take your parent or child to a doctor’s appointment in the middle of the day? Do it, and show your team that it’s okay to work nontraditional hours. Additionally, strive to create the conditions in which reports can ask for what they need — and work flexibility into ongoing performance conversations. “People, when given the room will advocate for their needs,” Auerbach said. “Create room for that.”
For Advice on How Managers and Leaders Can Model Flexibility, Read This Post.
Tips from an executive momthinkgrowth.org
  • For HR professionals: highlight flexibility. Mention flexibility in job descriptions, as well as other recruiting materials — before a candidate needs to awkwardly ask in their interview. Proactively present a variety of options and examples that show what flexible work looks like in your organization.
  • For working mothers, caregivers, and others who need a flexible schedule: ask for it. “Help your employer understand today why creating compatibility makes you more productive and where the ROI is. For better or for worse today you have to put it in business terms but there is a bottom line benefit of having employees on flexible schedules,” Auerbach said. “Speak up when something is causing you to fail.”
For Advice on How to Ask For Flexibility at Work (Even at a Small Business), Read This Post.
Tips from someone who has done itthinkgrowth.org
  • For everyone: Work to tear down the bias around flexibility. Be an upstander in conversations where people’s unconventional schedules or work styles are questioned.

As Auerbach put it: “Flexibility and ambition can and should exist.” I hope with a shared commitment to making a better, more inclusive workplace for all, I can someday rewrite the intro to this article to something more like this:

It’s always exciting when a coworker brings her new baby into the office for the first time. You bend down to the stroller, take a peek behind the blanket covering the tiny infant’s face, and exclaim, “Aww! She’s fantastic. I can’t wait to see her at the next board meeting. You’re presenting, right?”
